Honest Review of My Second NBA 2K Game

This is my second NBA 2K, and honestly, there are a lot of changes. Im really impressed with 2K26.
as a MyCareer lover, Im so happy that MyCareer has improved so much,the story feels immersive, the cutscenes make it feel like you‚Äôre actually living a career lmao
tbh Streetball mode is also way better than before,more enemy varieties now, and the smaller city makes the game more optimized.

Here are my pros and cons:

Pros

+ W Optimization
+ W Park / The City
+ W MyCareer (I really love the high school storyline ngl)
+ W Customization (so many cool cosmetics now)
+ W StreetsKing (Hardwood, Pivot, Jardhin)
+ W Crew System

 Cons

- L Matchmaking, in every park like Rec or Proving Grounds, it takes way too long to find opponents or teammates
- L VC price and bundles
- L Cosmetic prices,still way too expensive (please lower them!)
- L Squad Finder,not really useful

My Wishlist for 2K27:

Optimization is already good, but it can still be improved further in 2K27
Some recurring issues from 2K25 are still here in 2K26,like easy anti-cheat errors, online connection issues, etc.

I know there are fewer players on Steam compared to Console, and thats probably why matchmaking takes so long,but I really hope it gets much better in 2K27

This game is what happens when you have the resources to improve your game until perfection, but you just don't listen/care enough to fix issues, there are very polished aspects of the game, but most of these aspects are small things the fanbase doesn't want/care about. 

   -There are at least TWO SPELLING errors in the main storyline, not a big deal on its own, but this is a Colossus of a game as far as success, a spelling error is an easy fix for a company that cares.
   -If you flip through certain menus too abruptly, it can straight up just freeze your game, I was doing team practice in MyCareer and as I was deciding on a drill, poof! I couldn't do anything on my main monitor.
   -Simple quality of life features are lacking to a large extent, I went back to replay some of my already completed MyCareer storyline to see if there was something else I could do, and when I did, there were several unskippable cutscenes lasting minutes for events I had already played through.
   -There is STILL, after all these years of people complaining and negative attention, a very, very, heavy emphasis on "pay-to-progress" virtual currency packages, and I understand if you prefer to shell out the 100 USD or so that it costs to get to a maxed character, but it feels like half of the content in this game has a price tag next to it, it really makes you feel like you should just spend the money to avoid the grind.

   At the end of the day, I like NBA basketball, so I'm going to play NBA 2K at times, but if ten companies had the rights to make a game based on the NBA, NBA 2K would most likely be the 9th or 10th game I'd pick when I get the urge to shoot some hoops. I hope someday we can get something more similar to a passionate fan's project in the future, because tragically, the format has promise.

This is an in-depth critique of this horrendous game and franchise. I‚Äôm tired of how surface-level the praise and criticism of this series always are.

There‚Äôs this old shoemaker who‚Äôs too cheap to toss out an old mangled boot. Instead he keeps slapping patch after patch onto the same rotten leather. Each fix creates a new problem, so he patches that too, then patches the patch, until it becomes a towering, misshapen, unrecognizable pole of garbage. This is the 2K franchise.

This game is a decade-old skeleton propped up by duct tape and copium. 
People keep saying the series peaked at 2K11, 2K14, and 2K16. The movement is still the same bumper-car nonsense it has been since 2K14. Players snap to invisible grid points like they‚Äôre being teleported by a drunk stagehand. Footwork has no bearing on defense. It is a rubber-band tug-of-war where the engine jerks your player into angles at velocities no human body would survive. 
Locomotion, real physics, and actual momentum do not exist. What you get instead is a poorly choreographed imitation of offense and ball movement.

Passing is bipolar. The same input produces a different result every time. High passes never seem to exist unless the animation library feels generous. You can have Wembanyama wide open, yet the game throws a chest-high lob directly into Tyler Herro‚Äôs hands like you are secretly running point for the other team. Outlet passes trigger on pure whim. Magnetic steal animations bend the ball‚Äôs path as if the defender is an air bender. Passing drills are so broken they feel like parody.

The engine‚Äôs philosophy is simple: animation first, reality second, physics never.

Ballhandling is a shrine to invincibility frames. It would make fighting games blush.
Real basketball logic, such as protecting the ball or shielding it with the off-shoulder, means nothing. The dribble ball is glued to an animation tag instead of existing in actual space. You can read the ballhandler perfectly, cut the angle, watch them expose the ball like they are sleepwalking through a pickup game, and the game still hands you a reach-in foul for pressing steal. Meanwhile Unpluckable and its clones override basic logic and give even sloppy handlers a forcefield.

This is especially bad this year. The game will call you for a reach-in foul just for attempting a poke when the ballhandler is bulldozing through his defender and colliding with you while the on-ball hand is fully exposed. When Kyrie Irving, Wardell Stephen Curry, or Allen Iverson do that in real life, it is a miracle when the ball is not stripped. It is a highlight. In this game it happens every other possession and nobody bats an eye, yet you get punished for playing disciplined and sane on-ball defense.

Off-ball players are Stonehenge with jerseys. Without automatic playcalling or constant manual plays, four teammates plant themselves like ancient monuments. No off-ball screens. No intelligent cuts. No recognition of double teams. You can draw two defenders, leave an entire lane open, and your wide open teammate will still stand on the perimeter admiring scenery. Actual NBA role players, and even NBA busts, would riot if they had to run with this AI.

Now defense. Or rather the ghost of defense.
The coverage system is busted in ways that have never been fixed. The feedback does not reflect what your eyes see. The system‚Äôs bipolar tendencies return. Identical situations produce wildly different outcomes. A layup is labeled open, and the same layup against the same defender from almost the same position suddenly becomes heavily contested. I once had Kevin Love on the opposite side of the rim, barely even involved, a full step away with his hand lazily raised. Yet the coverage read 54 percent and called it heavily contested. The game created geometry that simply did not exist.
On ball defense is a joke. The player you are defending will warp past you half the time no matter how precise you try to be.

This engine can‚Äôt produce fluid motion, can‚Äôt respect spatial logic, and can‚Äôt simulate basic basketball IQ.
NBA 2K26 is a time capsule proving exactly how far a series can fall when it refuses to rebuild the foundation.

P.S. I forgot to add that the game actually has typos in numerous instances in interviews and such. Truly indicative of the love and care poured into this game
